revision.comment: removed [[Category:Equestrian statues in the United States]]; added [[Category:Equestrian statues in Washington, D.C.]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{other uses|George Washington (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Washington Circle Equestrian Statue.jpg | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 300px | title = Lieutenant General George Washington | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Clark Mills (sculptor) | year = 1860 | type = [[Bronze]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 9 | width_imperial = 14 | length_imperial = 6 | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Washington Circle]], [[Northwest, Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] | museum = | owner = [[National Park Service]] {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | nrhp_type = cp | nocat = yes | partof = [[American Revolution Statuary]]. | partof_refnum = 78000256<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> | location = [[Stanton Park]], [[Northeast, Washington, D.C.]] | lat_degrees = 38 | lat_minutes = 54 | lat_seconds = 8.45 | lat_direction = N | long_degrees =77 | long_minutes = 3 | long_seconds = 1.08 | long_direction = W | locmapin = United States Washington, D.C. | added = July 14, 1978 }} }} '''''Lieutenant General George Washington''''' is an equestrian statue of [[George Washington]], at [[Washington Circle]], [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=G1I98048Q3397.39158&menu=search&aspect=Keyword&npp=50&ipp=20&spp=20&profile=ariall&ri=&term=&index=.GW&aspect=Keyword&term=&index=.AW&term=&index=.TW&term=&index=.SW&term=&index=.FW&term=&index=.OW&term=77002483&index=.NW&x=9&y=10#focus "Lieutenant General George Washington, (sculpture)."] ''SIRIS''</ref>
==History== [[File:George Washington statue.JPG|thumb|left]] In 1783, after the close of the [[American Revolutionary War]], the [[Continental Congress]] ordered that an equestrian statue of Washington should be erected, the base of which should represent the principal incident of the war. For some reason the subject was dropped until after Washington's death, when in December, 1799, Congress resolved that a marble monument be erected by the United States Government. This was also, however, delayed, and in May, 1800, a third time it was decided that an erection of a costly mausoleum would resolve it. After talking, 1801, an appropriation of $800,000 was made for the purpose and the issue concerning the statue ended.<ref name=Nationalrep>{{cite news|last=Murtagh|first=W.J.|title=National Republican., February 17, 1873, Image 4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86053573/1873-02-17/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=23 March 2013|newspaper=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.|date=February 17, 1873}}</ref>
On February 13, 1832, a resolution of inquiry, introduced by Congressman (and later President) [[James Buchanan]] as to how the House resolution of 1799 had been carried out, was adopted. The House appointed a committee to make suitable arrangements for the celebration of the centennial anniversary of Washington's birth. This brought back to life the idea of creating a statue honoring [[George Washington]].<ref name=Nationalrep />
The equestrian statue was finally authorized by an act of Congress on January 25, 1853, and executed by sculptor [[Clark Mills (sculptor)|Clark Mills]], and dedicated on February 22, 1860, by President Buchanan.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.savefoggybottom.com/FBN/foggy-bottom-news/this-past-feb-22nd-marked-the-150th-anniversary-of-the-george-washington-statue-in-washington-circle/| title=The 150th Anniversary of the George Washington Statue in Washington Circle | date= March 6, 2010| work=Foggy Bottom Association}}</ref> It cost $60,000.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://media.www.gwhatchet.com/media/storage/paper332/news/2010/02/25/News/Community.Remembers.History.Behind.George.Washington.Sculpture-3879737.shtml| title=Community remembers history behind George Washington sculpture| author= Ashley Roberts | work=The GW Hatchet | date=2010-02-25 }}</ref>
Washington is pictured advancing in front of the American lines toward the British, with shot and cannonballs, at the [[Battle of Princeton]] and Trenton. He calmly hold the reins as he surveys the battle with unflinching determination.<ref name=Washington>{{cite book|last=Goode|first=James M.|title=Washington sculpture : a cultural history of outdoor sculpture in the nation's capital|year=2008|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|location=Baltimore|isbn=0801888107|page=480}}</ref>
The horse's mane is modeled on ''[[Napoleon Crossing the Alps]].'' Washington's rank during the war was not "Lieutenant General", as he was not promoted until the later [[Quasi-War]] of 1798.
After years of guarding Washington Circle for over a century, this equestrian statue was temporarily moved to allow for the construction of the K Street Underpass. In 1936, Washington and his horse were released from their wooden cage and returned to the center of the Washington Circle.<ref>''Washington sculpture: a cultural history of outdoor sculpture in the nation's capital''</ref>
As part of [[American Revolution Statuary]] in Washington, D.C. the statue is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].
==See also== * [[List of public art in Washington, D.C., Ward 2]]
